image.altText: A man on a stretcher is carried up the narrow bus steps

items.synopsis: On the frontlines of Vladimir Putin's war in Ukraine, soldiers are facing a brutal onslaught. It's up to a volunteer team of medics, the Hospitallers Battalion, to evacuate the wounded back to safety in a race against the clock.

title.children: If you're wounded on the frontlines of Ukraine's brutal war, Lidia and her high-tech bus are your best hope

image.altText: Marnus Labuschange puts on his gloves and carries his bat under his arm as he walks out to the middle

items.synopsis: Thanks to a fighting Marnus Labuschagne century — and more than a little help from the rain — Australia still holds out hope of rescuing a draw at Old Trafford, setting up yet another grandstand finish.

title.children: Labuschagne helps Australia rediscover its grit, setting up a final-day fight for the Ashes

image.altText: A blond woman taking a selfie outside with a bearded man next to her and two girls climbing on their back above them

items.synopsis: Influenza case numbers are soaring around the country, with young people and children the hardest hit. Some experts say it is time to make better of use of antivirals.

title.children: 'Simply too late': Flu season is so bad this year some experts are calling for more antiviral use

image.altText: A woman in a green dress with a buzzcut looks back at the camera in the middle of a grassy field

items.synopsis: Some young feminists in China are rebelling against mainstream beauty standards by embracing buzz cuts and ditching make-up.

title.children: Why young women in China are ditching 'beauty duty'

image.altText: Georgia Stanway celebrates

items.synopsis: England's well-fancied Lionesses needed a re-taken penalty to see off Haiti in their FIFA Women's World Cup opener. Earlier, former winners Japan and the USA recorded big wins over Zambia and Vietnam and Denmark secures late winner against China.

title.children: England labours to victory over exciting World Cup debutants Haiti, Denmark defeats China in late show in Perth

image.altText: Australia cricket captain Pat Cummins walks through the rain at Old Trafford in his team warm-up gear.

items.synopsis: Marnus Labuschagne stands tall for Australia before losing a battle with Joe Root on a rainy day four in Manchester. Here are the five things you missed overnight at Old Trafford.

title.children: Five quick hits — Root, rain and Labuschagne make for topsy-turvy day at Old Trafford

image.altText: Iannotta

items.synopsis: Angela Iannotta scored Australia's first ever World Cup goal at the 1995 Women's World Cup in Sweden — but there's hardly any proof it happened at all.

title.children: This Aussie champion scored our first goal in Women's World Cup history — but we can't show you footage of the moment

image.altText: Melanesian women in traditional face paint smiling widely

items.synopsis: The Melanesian Arts and Culture Festival in Port Vila, Vanuatu, platforms the song, dance and stories of one of the world's most culturally and linguistically diverse regions.

title.children: Colourful festival returns to celebrate one of the world's most diverse regions

image.altText: An F1 driver in a black F1 car dirving on track, with his head poking out of the cockpit.

items.synopsis: Lewis Hamilton is on pole in F1 for the first time since 2021, pipping Max Verstappen in Hungary by the barest of margins.

title.children: Hamilton breaks F1 record, beating Verstappen by 0.003 seconds in Hungary qualifying

image.altText: A teenaged girl sits on her bed with a wall of photos behind her, wearing beads and ends of hair dyed pink

items.synopsis: Like many teenagers, Ruby was struggling with her mental health. Then, like magic, music and a community of like minds came to the rescue.

title.children: 'Music is my superpower': How singing helped Ruby tackle depression

image.altText: A woman in a broad tan hat bends down while making a fire.

items.synopsis: Kellie Jackson has taught about 5,200 Canberran women survival skills, from using a compact mirror to attract attention to using tampons and lip balm to start a fire.

title.children: Using a mirror to attract attention or tampons and lip balm to start a fire: Kellie says women should know these survival skills

image.altText: A large ancient stone grinding tool that looks like a surfboard-shaped table with two thick legs.

items.synopsis: Analysis of micro-remnants found on a stone grinding tool in Southern Vietnam revealed a range of spices including ginger, nutmeg, and cinnamon.

title.children: Remnants of 2,000-year-old curry shed light on trade routes and role of spices in ancient civilisations

image.altText: An upturned white truck lying on grass.

items.synopsis: Jake Barrett, 29, awaits sentencing after pleading guilty to culpable driving causing death and grievous bodily harm, following the "horrific" crash in September 2021.

title.children: 'Dead because of me': Distracted truck driver's remorse after crash killed a man and seriously injured another

image.altText: Close-up photos of Gypsy Satterley and Jessica Townley

items.synopsis: Mother-of-two Gypsy Satterley and alpaca breeder Jessica Townley are remembered after their deaths in a horrific crash on Queensland's Sunshine Coast.

title.children: 'Trustworthy', 'beautiful soul': Loved ones express heartbreak following highway triple fatality

image.altText: Big nuke explosion

items.synopsis: Nevil Shute's classic novel of nuclear annihilation, On the Beach, was published in June 1957. But the threat he warned of is still very much at the top of our collective mind, writes Alexander Howard.

title.children: 'This is the way the world ends': Nevil Shute warned us of nuclear annihilation. It's still a hot-button issue

image.altText: Three young man in hats and sunglasses clown for the camera, blue skies green hill, one guy  holds his hand in a rock sign.

items.synopsis: Some might have been underwhelmed by the line-up or turned off by memories of last year's mud, but an estimated 35,000 music fans still think Splendour in the Grass is worth saving up for.

title.children: Splendour in the Grass experience still sweet enough to attract thousands of music fans

image.altText: An Australian male diver points to his gold medal after winning at the World Aquatics Championships.

items.synopsis: After China won gold in the opening 12 diving events at the World Aquatics Championships in Fukuoka, Australia's Cassiel Rousseau bucks the trend with victory in the men's 10-metre platform.

title.children: Aussie diver Rousseau wins historic world champs gold to deny China clean sweep

image.altText: A man who is homeless, sits in a tent with his dog, as night falls.

items.synopsis: As southern Europe grapples with extreme heat, Rome recorded a record high temperature of 41.8 Celsius, leaving many of the city's homeless with nowhere to cool down.

title.children: Italy's homeless struggle in ongoing heatwave

image.altText: A man in a suit and a purple scarf celebrates on a pitch with a shield lifted over his head.

items.synopsis: Under Sage's ownership, the men's team claimed the premiership in 2019 and the women's team won a premiership in 2014.

title.children: Perth Glory goes into receivership, ending Tony Sage's ownership

image.altText: A lead singer and a guitarist, wearing tuxidos, perform on stage in front of a drum set.

items.synopsis: In videos posted on social media, the band's frontman Matty Healy can be seen kissing bassist Ross MacDonald after criticising the Malaysian government's stance against homosexuality in a profanity-laden speech to the festival audience.

title.children: Malaysia halts music festival after same-sex kiss by UK band The 1975

image.altText: Hands using a computer mouse and keyboard

items.synopsis: A man who allegedly helped launder more than $170,000 stolen from Australian businesses via email scams has been brought down by a year-long investigation.

title.children: Alleged cyber mule accused of stealing $170k via email scams targeting Australian businesses

image.altText: Boxes of vapes stacked next to each other on display

items.synopsis: The South Australian government launches a $2 million advertising blitz to reduce the number of people taking up vaping and smoking, with a special focus on young people.

title.children: Vaping, smoking targeted in new campaigns released by the SA government

image.altText: Joe Biden standing at a podium wearing a blue suit and the US flag behind him.

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden announces seven US companies have made voluntary commitments to ensure their AI products are safe before release.

title.children: OpenAI, Google and other AI companies agree to White House safeguards

image.altText: A Collingwood AFL player pumps his fists as he celebrates a goal.

items.synopsis: Ladder leader Collingwood pips Port Adelaide by just two points following yet another dramatic fightback, while the Sydney Swans claim victory against Fremantle. Earlier, the Brisbane Lions held off Geelong, and Richmond and Carlton enjoyed contrasting wins.

title.children: Magpies edge Power in see-sawing classic, Swans triumph over Dockers

image.altText: A football team celebrates scoring a try

items.synopsis: After beating Melbourne for the first time in five years, Newcastle's finals dream is a step closer towards becoming a reality.

title.children: Drought-breaking victory could spur Newcastle to an NRL fairytale

image.altText: A firefighter works at a site of an administrative building heavily damaged by a Russian missile strike.

items.synopsis: The latest attacks on Ukrainian port cities damaged critical infrastructure and grain terminals. Experts say this latest escalation in the war could have far-reaching impacts on global food security.

title.children: Why is Russia bombing Ukraine ports and threatening Black Sea ships?

image.altText: A white man in dull clothing and a bright yellow cap kneels on the ground as he works in a square hole at a dig site.

items.synopsis: The result has confounded researchers, after geophysical surveys detected four anomalies that could indicate grave shafts, and cadaver dogs detected the scent of human remains.

title.children: Mystery continues as dig fails to turn up bodies of lost Native American schoolchildren

image.altText: Two guitarists with long hair rehearse in a rock band, with one on the right wearing a denim jacket, singing into a microphone.

items.synopsis: Perth has one of the most vibrant music scenes in Australia, but with the closure of another live venue, musicians are beginning to fear the worst.

title.children: Another one bites the dust: Fears for live music venues across Australia as Perth bar closes its doors

image.altText: A shirtless, blonde-haired baby in a nappy rides a rocking horse, with a line of other rocking horses behind it.

items.synopsis: Tommy Besant wakes up every morning in a messy work shed surrounded by tools, timber and a stable of elaborate rocking horses he's brought to life with his own hands – and he owes his obsession to a childhood gift from his father.

title.children: 'I live in the shed': Rocking horse craftsman's painstaking passion

image.altText: Image of a man and a woman standing in front of a box.

items.synopsis: The plant-based bio-wrap industry is challenging the dominance of petroleum-based plastics, as consumers become increasingly willing to pay for environmentally friendly alternatives.

title.children: The company turning French fries into eco-friendly cling wrap

image.altText: a composite image of two men one wearing glasses the other wearing a cap backwards looking at the camera

items.synopsis: NSW Police say the two men involved in the fatal boat crash in Sydney's east were not wearing life jackets, as the search for the second man, Andrew Findlay, is scaled back.

title.children: 'Horrendous accident': Second man presumed dead after Sydney boat crash that claimed life of art dealer

image.altText: A close-up of hands holding a large green and yellow rock

items.synopsis: Gemfields residents heard the tale of a 424-carat sapphire being found, but thought it was a tourism ploy. It turns out the stone is real and the lucky finder has returned to set the record straight.

title.children: The tall but true tale of how a retiree found a $300,000 gemstone in Queensland's Central Highlands
